title: Nursing Research I
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD in Nursing
description: This course is designed for research students to explore recent research developments in nursing in order to facilitate them to identify interesting and important research areas.
outcome: This course will enable students to: • Critically discuss their own and others’ research problems and the significance to the professional development in nursing.  • Understand the applications of different research methodologies as scientific tools to address various clinical and professional issues in nursing. • Critically discuss and evaluate the methodological issues arising from the research presentation.  • Disseminate their research proposal and findings effectively, and demonstrate the techniques to justify all the decisions involved in the study design, results interpretation and discussions.  • Engage constructively in the scholarly discussion of research presentations.

title: Nursing Research II
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD in Nursing
description: This course is designed for research students to explore recent research developments in nursing in order to facilitate them to identify interesting and important research areas.
outcome: This course will enable students to: • Critically discuss their own and others’ research problems and the significance to the professional development in nursing.  • Understand the applications of different research methodologies as scientific tools to address various clinical and professional issues in nursing. • Critically discuss and evaluate the methodological issues arising from the research presentation.  • Disseminate their research proposal and findings effectively, and demonstrate the techniques to justify all the decisions involved in the study design, results interpretation and discussions.  • Engage constructively in the scholarly discussion of research presentations.

title: Research Seminar
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD in Nursing
description: The seminars, offered in each term of the programme, aim to help students gain skills in presenting and developing ideas for their research study as well as allowing the exchange of ideas and methodological issues between students and academic staff contributing to the development of the student's thesis.
outcome: This course will enable students to: • Critically discuss their own and others’ research problems and the significance to the professional development in nursing.  • Understand the applications of different research methodologies as scientific tools to address various clinical and professional issues in nursing. • Critically discuss and evaluate the methodological issues arising from the research presentation.  • Disseminate their research proposal and findings effectively, and demonstrate the techniques to justify all the decisions involved in the study design, results interpretation and discussions.  • Engage constructively in the scholarly discussion of research presentations.

title: Advancing Nursing Science I
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD in Nursing
description: This research unit provides students with continuing supervision and monitoring of their progress in developing and writing up their theses.
outcome: The course will enable students to: 1. Analyse the implications of nursing knowledge for their chosen research topic; 2. Critically assess the contribution of the literature to their research study; 3. Analyse the appropriateness of different research designs to the context of the research study; 4. Justify the appropriateness of the sampling designs and methods selected for their research study; 5. Analyse and evaluate methods of data collection in the context of their research study; 6. Evaluate the contribution of different methods of data analysis to their research study; 7. Practise and evaluate a range of data collection and data analysis techniques; 8. Examine the processes of systematic reviews as the foundation for informed clinical practice. 9. Develop techniques to appraise, extract and pooling of data collected through the systematic review process. 10 Develop a proposal for their research study.

title: Specialisation in Advanced Nursing Practice I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing and Doctor of Nursing
description: This course aims to prepare students for competent delivery of nursing care and services in the designated nursing specialty, or assumption of nursing management roles in the complex healthcare environment. The course provides students with requisite specialty knowledge and skills for advanced care management and patient care, or advanced practice in management and leadership. In addition, the course develops students’ understanding of evidence-based concepts and ability to apply knowledge of evidence-based practice to enhance quality of healthcare services.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. apply essential knowledge and skills in the advanced nursing practice. 2. integrate assessment findings into planning of interventions for clients in advanced nursing practice.3. identify evidence-based interventions for advanced nursing practice. 4. deliver interventions to clients of the designated nursing specialty safely and effectively. 5. evaluate the effectiveness of existing interventions in advanced nursing practice. 6. apply knowledge of evidence-based practice to enhance quality of healthcare services.

title: Specialisation in Advanced Nursing Practice II
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing and Doctor of Nursing
description: This course aims to prepare students for competent delivery of nursing care and services in the designated nursing specialty, or assumption of nursing management roles in the complex healthcare environment. The course provides students with requisite specialty knowledge and skills for advanced care management and patient care, or advanced practice in management and leadership. It also emphasises quality of care and safety in specialty nursing. In addition, the course strengthens students’ knowledge of nursing informatics and deepens their understanding of ethical and legal aspects in specialty nursing.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. apply advanced knowledge and skills in the designated nursing specialty/ healthcare management. 2. integrate assessment findings into planning of interventions for clients in advanced nursing practice.3. identify evidence-based interventions for advanced nursing practice. 4. deliver interventions to clients of the designated nursing specialty safely and effectively. 5. evaluate the effectiveness of existing interventions in advanced nursing practice. 6. discuss quality and safety issues in advanced nursing practice. 7. describe nursing informatics and use of information technology in health care. 8. discuss a range of ethical and legal issues in relation to professional practice.

title: Professional Skill Competency
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course aims to build up students’ professional skill competency in advanced nursing practice. It is designed to enable students to apply the knowledge and skills they have learned in the previous courses in their specialty. The emphasis is on out-of-class professional learning experience and reflective learning of professional skills through regular interactions with clinical nursing experts in the designated nursing specialty. In addition, supplementary learning activities such as virtual reality laboratory practice, reflective reports, portfolios, and group discussions are used to enhance students’ mastery of the professional skills.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. apply the knowledge and skills of the designated nursing specialty in clinical practice. 2. reflect on personal mastery of professional skills in the designated nursing specialty. 3. discuss clinical cases as specialty nurses. 4. demonstrate professional skill competency in the designated nursing specialty.

title: Scholarly Inquiry I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course aims to help students develop knowledge and skills to critically appraise literature resources with a focus on advanced nursing practice. This will involve analyzing the contribution of research and appropriateness of the research approaches to knowledge development.

title: Scholarly Inquiry II
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course provides students with opportunities to broaden their knowledge on quantitative and qualitative research methodologies, service development, and analysis of healthcare provision. It enables students to develop a scholarly inquiry proposal and conduct a scholarly inquiry project.

title: Scholarly Inquiry
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills to critically appraise literature and summarise evidence to improve nursing practice and health outcomes of individuals and populations. This will involve analysing the contribution of research and the appropriateness of the research approaches to knowledge development.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. analyse the processes for establishing current evidence for specific areas of nursing practice.  2. identify the benefits and limitations of evidence-based practice.  3. critically review the literature that underlies a selected healthcare topic.  4. evaluate the designs and methods commonly used in research and service innovation project.  5. discuss the quality of measurement in both quantitative and qualitative research.  6. develop a critical review of the literature in a selected area of a nursing topic.

title: Contemporary Issues in Advanced Nursing Practice
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course aims to enable students to expand knowledge and understanding of nursing practice in a diverse context. The course covers theoretical foundation of nursing practice, social determinants of health in relation to various populations including children, adolescents, older people and families, healthcare policy, healthcare financing, healthcare system organisation, human diversity and social issues that influence nursing practice. The course also enables students to discuss strategies, approaches and interventions to address the emerging health issues.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. examine the fundamental concepts, beliefs and values of nursing models in the context of contemporary healthcare environment.  2. describe health equity issues and specific health needs of different populations. 3. discuss the professional role of nurses and the scope of nursing practice in a diverse context. 4. critically appraise the recent healthcare policy initiatives, healthcare financing and healthcare system organisation, and their impacts on population health.  5. discuss strategies, approaches and interventions to health promotion, disease prevention and health restoration.

title: Advanced Health Assessment and Clinical Judgment
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing or Doctor of Nursing
description: This course provides students with opportunities to apply their knowledge and skills of comprehensive history taking and physical assessment to both healthcare and community settings, with emphasis on differentiation between normal and abnormal findings, identification of common health problems, process of critical thinking and clinical judgment through analysis of clinical findings.

title: Evidence-based Practice for Quality Care
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing or Doctor of Nursing
description: This course facilitates students to expand their scope of clinical practice by undertaking an in-depth examination of their specialty area of practice. Students are expected to further develop their skills in clinical decision-making and to promote evidence-based practice in their relevant clinical specialty.

title: Clinical Leadership, Management and Outcome Evaluation
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing or Doctor of Nursing
description: This course focuses on developing students' understanding of healthcare management, leadership and the process of health outcome evaluation. Related frameworks for healthcare management, continuous quality improvement and outcome evaluations will be explored to guide students in assuming a managerial role and making quality improvement decisions in their specialty practice.

title: Student-led Seminar I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This seminar aims to provide students with opportunities to present and share their scholarly inquiry project with their peers and the academic staff. It emphasizes on the critical review of the literature related to the project. In addition, reflection of the process of literature review and the strategies used to overcome difficulties during the development of the scholarly inquiry project will be shared and discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. Describe and justify the literature and research methods selected to inform the development of their scholarly inquiry project.  2. Use appropriate strategies to search the literature relevant to their project.  3. Critically analyze the research methods and the literature related to their own project or the projects presented by their peers.  4. Discuss significant issues related to their own and their peers’ review of the literature. 5. Discuss and reflect the process of literature review and the strategies used to overcome difficulties during the development of the scholarly inquiry project. 6. Present their scholarly inquiry project in a clear and logical manner.

title: Student-led Seminar II
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This seminar aims to provide students with opportunities to present and share with their peers and the academic staff about the research method or project plan of their scholarly inquiry project. In addition, reflection of the development process of research method or project plan and the strategies used to overcome difficulties during the process will be shared and discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. Describe the research method/project plan developed for their scholarly inquiry project, and present the innovative materials if applicable. 2. Critically evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of the selected research method/innovation. 3. Critically review the findings obtained from the study, if applicable. 4. Critically analyze the research methods/project plans presented by their peers. 5. Discuss significant issues related to their own and their peers’ research methods/project plans. 6.  Present their project in a clear and logical manner.

title: Advanced Biostatistics in Evidence-based Practice Research
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: The aim of this elective course is to provide students with an advanced level of knowledge in biostatistics and to enable them to appropriately apply such knowledge for evaluating nursing innovation in the complex health care context. This course also enables the students to have an advanced level of statistical literacy to appraise the science in nursing and health care.

title: Applied Statistics for Evidence-based Practice
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: The course aims to provide students with an advanced level of knowledge in statistics to enable them to appropriately apply such knowledge for evaluating nursing innovation in the complex healthcare context. It also enables the students to have an advanced level of statistical literacy to appraise the science in nursing and health care. The course covers regression modelling, psychometric evaluation methods, repeated measures, factors analysis, and structural equation modelling.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. develop the knowledge and skills to read, critically evaluate, and discuss the statistical methods in scientific nursing literature. 2. critically discuss the methods and considerations in identifying appropriate statistical methods for evaluating an evidence-based nursing practice. 3. develop the knowledge and skills in conducting a variety of statistical techniques for evaluating the effects of an evidence-based nursing practice. 4. develop the knowledge and skills in adopting a variety of statistical techniques to estimate sample size required for evaluating an evidence-based nursing practice.

title: Scholarly Inquiry Project
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing
description: This course facilitates students to undertake a scholarly inquiry project for knowledge development and transfer. Students are required to complete a research or service innovation project, and are expected to integrate the knowledge that have been obtained from Scholarly Inquiry I & II into this project.
outcome: At the end of this course, students will be able to: 1. Evaluate and critique the existing nursing practice in a selected clinical setting. 2. Initiate innovation through a research/ service innovation project approach to enhance advanced practice in a selected clinical setting. 3. Demonstrate critical thinking skills in integrating the analysis and synthesis of the evidence-based nursing knowledge into their writing.  4. Disseminate significant components of the research/ service innovation project for knowledge development and transfer. 5. Utilize the research findings to meet the changing healthcare needs and to enhance the quality of care.

title: Fundamentals of Nursing I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to equip students with fundamental and essential nursing skills for promoting the health and wellness of clients. Emphasis will be placed on promoting students' understanding of the application of basic nursing care principles to safely help clients meet their basic needs of living.
outcome: At the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. Apply communication skills in dealing with individuals across their life span and members of the healthcare team. 2. Demonstrate essential nursing techniques like reporting and documentation skills. 3. Exhibit understanding and skills in helping clients meet their basic needs of living, including maintaining body temperature, promoting rest and sleep, and meeting activity and mobility needs. 4. Demonstrate ability to perform health assessment for individuals using a systematic approach.

title: Fundamentals of Nursing II
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to equip students with fundamental and essential nursing skills for promoting the health and wellness of clients. Emphasis will be placed on promoting students' understanding of the application of basic principles of nursing care to safely help clients meet their basic needs of living. Drug administration skills will also be included.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: 1. Discuss the nursing skills in helping clients to meet their basic needs of living including safety needs, promoting hygiene, bowel elimination needs, wound care, and pain relief. 2. Discuss the essential nursing skills including maintaining a safe and comfortable environment for care, and infection control. 3. Discuss the nursing skills in promoting the client’s sexual health. 4. Discuss the nursing skills in helping clients to meet their psychosocial and spiritual needs of hospitalization and cope with loss, grief, and death. 5. Describe nursing responsibilities in preparing and assisting the client to undertake diagnostic procedures.  6. Apply the basic principles of pharmacological interventions in clinical nursing practice.

title: Fundamentals of Nursing III
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to equip students with fundamental and essential nursing skills for promoting the health and wellness of clients. Emphasis will be placed on promoting students' understanding of the application of basic principles of nursing care to safely help clients meet their basic needs of living.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Apply principles and research findings from the biological, behavioural, and nursing sciences to meet clients’ basic needs of living, including respiratory, fluid and nutrition, and urinary elimination. 2. Demonstrate skills and knowledge in helping clients meet their respiratory, fluid and nutritional, and urinary elimination needs. 3. Discuss the screening and monitoring processes of children at risk for developmental problems. 4. Apply the basic principles of pharmacological interventions in clinical nursing practice.

title: Anatomy I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to provide students with basic knowledge of human topographical anatomy with emphasis on those aspects of special signifi cance in the nursing practice. The course will partially run concurrently with that of physiology. The syllabus will be integrated so that students will be able to correlate structure and function.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Understand the different cell and tissue types of the body. 2. Understand the importance of cell and tissue structures to their functions. 3. Be acquainted with the general organization of the organs in the body and how they organize to form a functional system. 4. Learn the importance of the structural relationship and arrangement in the clinical setting. 5. Describe both the macroscopic and microscopic structures of the organs, and relate them to the functions of the organs. 6. Learn the origin and development of the organs and the associated birth defects.

title: Anatomy II
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to provide students with a basic knowledge of human topographical anatomy with emphasis on those aspects of special significance in nursing practice. The course will partially run concurrently with that in physiology. The syllabus will be integrated so that students will be able to correlate structure and function.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Understand the organization of the organs in the digestive and reproductive systems. 2. Learn the importance of the structural relationship and arrangement of the organs in the clinical setting. 3. Understand both the macroscopic and microscopic structures of the organs, and relate them to the functions of the organs. 4. Learn the development of the organs and the associated birth defects. 5. Learn the basic components and the entire organization of the nervous system. 6. Learn the basic functions of the different parts of the brain and their associations. 7. Learn the different communication pathways between the brain and the body and their functions. 8. Learn the composition of the eye and ear and the related pathways

title: Physiology I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: The aim of the course is to enhance students' knowledge and understanding of how the body adapts physiologically to internal and external environmental changes. It focuses on the physiological principles of normal cells, tissues, and system functioning which will form the basis for studying health promotion, pathology, and nursing care. The course content will be partially integrated with that offered in Anatomy.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Describe the electrical properties of a neuron and understand the physiological significance of transmission of nerve impulse. 2. Explain how a skeletal muscle contracts and recognize the importance of neuromuscular transmission in a human body. 3. Discuss how the cardiovascular system helps regulate blood perfusion in body tissues. 4. Describe and explain how homeostasis helps maintain physiological functions such as thermoregulation. 5. Summarize how some of the altered functions in the cardiovascular and pulmonary systems affect the body. 6. Explain how the pulmonary system and blood transport oxygen to tissues and carbon dioxide from the tissues. 7. Outline the roles of blood in hemostasis and immune defense.

description: The aim of the course is to enhance students' knowledge and understanding of how the body adapts physiologically to internal and external environmental changes. Focus will be given on the physiological principles of normal cells, tissues, and system functioning. These will form the basis for studying health promotion, pathology, and nursing care. The course content will be partially integrated with that offered in Anatomy.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Describe the processes by how the kidneys regulate the body fluid volume and its composition. 2. Understand how the gastrointestinal system carries out the digestion and absorption of ingested food. 3. Summarize the roles of various hormones and understand the mechanisms of their secretions 4. Recall the structure of the nervous system and understand how autonomic nervous system affects body functions 5. Explain how the special senses particularly the eyes and ears function in human 6. Outline how some of the altered functions in the kidneys, gastrointestinal, endocrine, and central nervous system affect the body 7. Summarize the general principles on how the tissues and organs work altogether to maintain homeostasis

title: Fundamental Pharmacology
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to enhance students' knowledge related to the principles of pharmacology and drug information resources. It also seeks to stimulate their critical thinking in identifying specific nursing implications for drug therapy and knowledge application in clinical situations.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Understand the principles and concepts of pharmacology. 2. Differentiate between the principles of pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics, and apply knowledge in clinical situations. 3. Ensure safe practice when administering medications to clients in clinical situations.  4. Demonstrate the ability to report and document the nursing actions and care delivered. 5. Understand the basic concepts of pharmacy law and ordinance.

title: Microbiology
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to provide students with basic understanding of microbiology. It emphasizes microorganisms commonly found in human and those that are potentially pathogenic. Methods for prevention and control in the hospital setting are introduced.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Demonstrate a basic understanding of micro-organisms that are potentially pathogenic to human, relevant investigation and management. 2. Demonstrate the basic concepts of infection control. 3. Demonstrate the ability to use Personal Protective Equipment appropriately.

title: Nursing Development and Trends
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course comprises of several parts, including: The development of the philosophy and knowledge base in nursing which enables students develop their understanding of its evolution; The application of technology in information processing for nursing practice and research, including the systems available for hospital information and nursing management; An integrated study of professional issues related to nursing that will enhance students' educational and professional self-direction.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Examine the factors influencing the future directions of nursing practice. 2. Understand the health and illness concept and the effect of socio-cultural factors on individual health. 3. Recognize the nursing process as a problem solving approach in the care of clients. 4. Explain the methods for assuring quality in health care by nurses and the health care team. 5. Compare and contrast different approaches to career ladders in nursing. 6. Examine the challenges in professional development of nursing in Hong Kong. 7. Compare and contrast different health system models. 8. Analyze the challenges of reforming Hong Kong’s health system. 9. Analyze the advantages and limitations of using computer applications in the management of information. 10. Examine the implications of information technology for practice, research and education.  11. Determine and apply the ethical and legal principles in the use of information technology.

title: Applied Psychology in Nursing
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to provide theoretical basis on the foundations of psychology from a health-illness perspective. It includes the principles of psychology related to health. The consequences of illness and the impact of hospitalization for individuals, families, and society, as well as supportive systems will be examined.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Recognize the contribution of psychology to the understanding of health and illness. 2. Examine the influence of health beliefs on people’s health-related behaviours and practices. 3. Analyze the impact of illness and hospitalization on individuals, families, and the society. 4. Discuss the contribution of psychology to health promotion and disease prevention.  5. Analyze the application of health psychology to clinical nursing practice or health care.

title: Care for Clients with Acute and Chronic Illnesses I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course emphasizes basic nursing knowledge, including the pathophysiological changes and pharmacological treatment of clients with acute and chronic illnesses. Students are equipped with the principles of therapeutic management and nursing skills to assess, diagnose, and implement evidence-based nursing interventions. Overall, it aims to promote health outcomes of these clients.

title: Care for Clients with Acute and Chronic Illnesses II
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course emphasizes basic nursing knowledge, particularly the pathophysiological changes and pharmacological treatment of clients with acute and chronic illnesses. Students are equipped with principles of therapeutic management and nursing skills. This will enable them to assess, diagnose, and implement evidence-based nursing interventions in promoting good health outcomes of their clients.
outcome: Students will be able to:  1. Appraise the bio-psychosocial dimensions of nursing practice, including the pathophysiological basis and body adaptation to the disease process, client education and psychosocial support to clients and their families. 2. Apply knowledge of pharmacology in caring for clients with acute and chronic illnesses. 3. Apply principles and utilize research findings from the biological, behavioural and nursing sciences in the care of clients with respiratory, genito-urinary, haematological, ophthalmic, oto-rhino-laryngological, and reproductive conditions. 4. Demonstrate ability to offer psychosocial support and interventions in caring for clients and families experiencing acute and chronic illnesses.  5. Formulate a nursing care plan appropriate to the health condition identified in the nursing assessment process. 6. Compose outcome measures to evaluate and document the effects of nursing interventions. 7. Demonstrate ability to perform nursing skills safely and efficiently in the laboratory and clinical settings.

title: Care for Clients with Acute and Chronic Illnesses III
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course emphasizes on basic nursing knowledge, particularly the pathophysiological changes and pharmacological treatment of clients with acute and chronic illnesses. Students are equipped with principles of therapeutic management and nursing skills to assess, diagnose, and implement evidence-based nursing interventions to promote good health outcomes of these clients.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Perform a comprehensive health and focus assessment of clients with altered functional health patterns.  2. Analyze assessment data to diagnose actual and potential alterations in functional health patterns. 3. Apply pharmacology knowledge in caring for clients with acute and chronic illnesses. 4. Apply nursing research findings in planning the care for the clients of the following disorders: clients with endocrine, cardiovascular, dermatological, neurological disorders; clients requiring palliative and rehabilitation nursing care. 5. Integrate psychosocial support and nursing care interventions to clients and their families with acute and chronic illnesses.

title: Legal and Ethical Issues in Nursing
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to develop students' critical thinking in the identifi cation of legal and ethical issues relevant to nursing. It will focus on: legal principles governing professional practice in Hong Kong, including torts, contract, confidentiality, informed consent, and related ordinances; basic ethical principles and theories related to the nursing practice; and ethical issues and dilemmas encountered in the practice.

title: Mental Health Nursing
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course provides theoretical basis for comprehensive nursing care to clients with alterations of mental health. It emphasizes on the approach that mental health and illnesses exist on a continuum. Students are equipped with knowledge to examine a variety of mental health disorders and to explore different mental health care settings.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Distinguish different types of mental disorders, discuss related signs and symptoms and outline core treatment modalities. 2. Critically analyze the major socio-economical, environmental and political contexts impacting mental health service provision in Hong Kong. 3. Assess the psychosocial health needs of clients with mental health problems. 4. Critically analyze health assessment data to identify clients’ problems and prioritize their healthcare needs. 5. Apply and integrate theoretical input into effective bio-psychosocial nursing interventions in the assessment, planning, implementation and evaluation of client-focused care. 6. Demonstrate an awareness of the importance of safe, ethical and legal nursing practice.

title: Public Health and Community Nursing
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to provide a theoretical foundation to public health concepts and community nursing. Its emphasis is placed on understanding the public health principles as well as the community nursing assessment and management of common health issues. Furthermore, it aims to encourage critical thinking in assessments, formulation of appropriate nursing diagnoses, and application of evidence-based interventions during the planning and delivery of care. Overall, it is intended to promote individual and family health.

title: Gerontological Nursing
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to provide theoretical and practical information on basic and complex health concepts and issues relevant to the continuum of care for older people. It emphasizes on the application of critical thinking and research evidence in assessing the diagnosed alterations of health among older people. In other words, this provides appropriate nursing interventions in promoting the health of the aged.
outcome: After completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. Describe the principles of gerontology and the roles of gerontological nursing. 2. Evaluate the age-related physiological and psychological changes during the aging process. 3. Analyse the physical and biopsychosocial changes in older people with the functional health pattern framework. 4. Demonstrate comprehensive health and social assessment and nursing care for older people. 5. Analyse the assessment data for diagnosing actual and potential physical and psychosocial problems and provide relevant nursing care. 6. Integrate psychosocial nursing interventions when planning care for older people and their carers.

title: Paediatric and Adolescent Nursing
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to provide theoretical and practical information on basic and complex health concepts and issues. It is focused on the nursing care of children and adolescents with physical, psychosocial, or developmental problems. It includes the principles of family centered nursing to provide comprehensive assessment and appropriate nursing interventions towards health promotion of clients.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Apply the principles of family centred nursing to assess the health problems among children and adolescences. 2. Understand the health concepts and issues relevant to nursing care of children and adolescents with physical, psychosocial, or developmental problems 3. Differentiate between health assessment and the required nursing care across the life-span of young-age clients. 4. Integrate psychosocial nursing interventions when planning care.

title: Nursing Research
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course will provide students with an understanding of nursing research principles to build their knowledge on evidence based nursing. This will be carried out by introducing students to the use of qualitative and quantitative research methods, research designs, and the research questions used in practice. These will enable students to conduct a critical literature review of a particular clinical practice area.
outcome: Students will be able to:  1. Examine the nursing research contributions to the development of evidence-based practice. 2. Identify the purpose and methods of conducting literature review. 3. Compare and contrast the characteristics, applications, strengths, and weakness of various study designs in both quantitative and qualitative research. 4. Examine and evaluate various sampling methods and data collection approaches. 5. Understand the principles and applications of quantitative and qualitative data analyses. 6. Examine the ethical implications of conducting research in clinical practice settings. 7. Evaluate the significance of research studies in advancing nursing practice.

title: Sociology of Health & Nursing
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course is designed to provide students with a sociological perspective on health and illness which is applicable to the nursing practice in Hong Kong. As a result, students will be able to understand different social sciences theories and concepts relevant to nursing and/or health care in general. Hence, the social forces leading to health promotion and illness prevention for individuals and families in society are examined.

title: Obstetric Nursing
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to introduce developmental physiological adaptations in women reproductive processes. This includes the knowledge of relevant anatomy and physiology, the process of pregnancy/postpartum, nursing care of fetus, neonate, and infancy with an emphasis on their implications in an evidence-based nursing practice.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Examine the basic concepts of obstetric nursing in the promotion of the health and wellness of the expectant family. 2. Apply family-centered care to the clients in normal pregnancy, labour and puerperium. 3. Discuss midwifery responsibilities in preparing and assisting the client and family to provide newborn care. 4. Describe principles and knowledge underlying the performance of essential skills.

title: Health Education and Health Promotion
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to develop students' understanding of a nurse's role in health promotion when working with individuals, groups, families, and communities. Its emphasis lies on the application of health education and promotion principles, as well as critiquing programmes relevant to local, current, and predicted health needs.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Examine the role of the nurse in undertaking health promotion with individuals, groups, families and communities. 2. Analyse current theories and models of health education and health promotion and their values in the delivery of such programmes. 3. Examine the contribution of health education to health promotion. 4. Analyse the changing pattern of community health and identify priorities and opportunities for health promotion. 5. Assess the learning needs of individuals, families, groups and communities. 6. Apply principles of health promotion to the implementation of programmes. 7. Evaluate the process and outcome of health promotion programmes for both the nurses and clients.

title: Complementary and Alternative Medicine
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course aims to introduce students to the efficacy, choice, use, and explanatory mechanisms of complementary and alternative medicine using a range of selected therapies. The regional focus will be on the health concepts of Traditional Chinese Medicine (including tai chi, qigong, and acupuncture). The scope and responsibilities of the nurse's role within this field in Hong Kong will also be discussed.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Demonstrate an understanding of the health concepts of Chinese medicine. 2. Interpret the basic theories of Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) such as Yin and Yang, the Five Vital Primary Elements, Zang Fu Theory and Meridians.  3. Describe the special features of modern Chinese medicine. 4. Identify the diagnostic and therapeutic methods of Chinese medicine. 5. Recognize the basic concepts about Chinese herbs and medications 6. Identify the scopes and principles of Chinese Medicine Nursing. 7. Understand the characteristics of complementary & alternative medicine (CAM).  8. Illustrate some common contemporary therapy systems and approaches in CAM.

title: Nursing Management and Health Care Policies
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: This course will enable students to expand their theoretical and skills-based knowledge in coordinating individual client care and organizing care for groups of clients in both hospital and community settings. Emphasis will be on leadership and management skills to maximize clients' outcomes, and the importance of multidisciplinary teamwork. An introduction of theories and processes of health care policy-making will also be included.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Explain how leadership skills of motivating, influencing, negotiating, delegating, and supervising can improve the quality of patient care. 2. Apply effective communication and team building skills in the coordination of nursing practice. 3. Discuss strategies to manage conflict and/or complaints effectively. 4. Analyze the theories of change and their implications for nursing practice. 5. Evaluate different strategies in change management. 6. Describe health care systems and health economics. 7. Analyze health service innovations in response to changing social and health care needs in Hong Kong. 8. Explain politics and power in health care policy-making.

title: Essence of Advanced Nursing Practice
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration)
description: The course is designed to promote the students' understanding of the development of advanced nursing practice and the roles of advanced practitioner. Also, the students will be expected to apply common advanced nursing knowledge, skills, and principles of scientific investigation to substantiate their clinical practice.
outcome: After completion of the course, students will be able to: 1. Examine the importance of advanced nursing practice issues 2. Analyze the factors that influence future directions of nursing practice. 3. Explore methods in assuring the quality of health care provided by nurses and the health care team as a whole. 4. Apply commonly used advanced practice skills in caring for patients. 5. Demonstrate competence in management of patients with various conditions.

title: Clinical Practice Block I
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration);Prerequisite: NURS6201, NURS6202 and NURS6203
description: This clinical practice block aims to provide students with a venue to apply and consolidate their knowledge and skills on interpersonal communication, client safety, health assessment, and basic nursing skills. In the process, they are able to promote clients' health and wellness. In addition, this clinical practice block allows students to gain understanding and experiential learning on various matters. These include clinical practice environment, nurses and health care team members' roles, and the health care delivery system in Hong Kong.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Develop an overall understanding of roles of nurses, medical and health care professionals and appreciate the health care systems. 2. Develop effective and therapeutic communication skills. 3. Develop comprehensive health assessment skills using Gordon’s Functional Health Patterns. 4. Demonstrate the ability to plan, implement, and evaluate individualized nursing care. 5. Apply knowledge and nursing skills safely in the provision of care. 6. Demonstrate proficiency in nursing skills that promote the health and wellness of clients. 7. Integrate the knowledge from anatomy, physiology, and microbiology in the provision of care. 8. Demonstrate the knowledge and skills of basic infection control. 9. Demonstrate the ability to evaluate and document health assessment findings and nursing care delivered. 10. Apply the principle of teaching and learning in planning and implementing health education and health promotion with clients.

title: Clinical Practice Block II
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration);Prerequisite: NURS6304
description: These clinical practice blocks aim to provide students with clinical practice opportunities in order to apply principles, concepts, and theories for the care of clients with surgical conditions. Students will be given the chance to practice in a hospital setting. Facilitators will assist them to develop clinical problem-solving skills and to apply a nursing care plan in clinical settings. This will assist students in their transition to become Registered Nurses. In other words, their integration into the health care team in clinical practice will be facilitated.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Apply a problem-solving approach in the identification and management of biopsychosocial health-related problems. 2. Demonstrate the ability to perform comprehensive and focus assessment of clients with surgical and orthopaedic alterations.  3. Demonstrate the ability to plan, implement, and evaluate individualized nursing care.  4. Deliver nursing care in a professional manner that is sensitive to client diversity.  5. Demonstrate effective communication with clients, their families, and health care team members.  6. Demonstrate competency in safe and efficient performance of nursing skills in the clinical settings.  7. Integrate the knowledge of pathophysiology, clinical manifestations, treatment, and pharmacotherapy to care for clients with different health disorders.  8. Apply the principle of teaching and learning in planning and implementing health education and health promotion to clients.  9. Relate research findings to the provision of health promotion and nursing care in terms of process and outcomes.  10. Demonstrate accountability and apply ethical and legal considerations in nursing practice.  11. Begin to practice critical thinking and clinical judgment by applying theoretical knowledge into practical experience.  12. Develop skills in self and peer appraisal of nursing care through reflections.

title: Clinical Practice Block III
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration);Prerequisite: NURS6305
description: This clinical practice block aims to provide students with clinical practice opportunities to apply principles, concepts, and theories for the care of clients with various specialty conditions. These conditions include: psychiatric, obstetric, those requiring surgical operation, and community nursing care. Students will be given the chance to practice in both community and hospital settings. They will be assisted in developing clinical problem-solving skills and the use of a nursing care plan in clinical settings. This will assist students during their transition to become Registered Nurses. In other words, their integration into the health care team in clinical practice will be facilitated.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Identify the roles of different discipline in the care of clients and their family members with complex health problem. 2. Apply problem-solving approach in the identification and management of biopsychosocial health-related problems of clients. 3. Demonstrate a comprehensive and focused health assessment of individuals. Critically analyze health assessment data to identify, prioritize problems, and develop plans of care supported by research evidences. 4. Demonstrate competence in the safe and efficient performance of nursing skills in various clinical specialties, and in preparation and aftercare for investigative procedures. 5. Demonstrate effective communication with clients, their families, and multidisciplinary health care team members. 6. In partnership with client, facilitate the client’s psychosocial adaptation to experiencing moderate to severe health problems. 7. Establish ability to identify research topics from theoretical knowledge and practical experience.  8. Develop critical thinking skills and clinical judgment from theoretical knowledge and practical experience. 9. Demonstrate skills in self and peer appraisals of nursing techniques and care through reflections. 10. Evaluate and document assessment, care planning and implementation of care. 11. Demonstrate skills of coordinating the care for a group of clients.

title: Clinical Practice Block IV
requirements: For students in Master of Nursing Science (Pre-registration);Prerequisite: NURS6305
description: These blocks aim to provide students with clinical practice opportunities in order to apply principles, concepts, and theories for the care of clients with various specialty conditions. These conditions include medical, geriatrics, paediatrics, and emergency. In addition, this will allow students to have clinical practice opportunities in caring for pediatric and geriatric clients. The students will be given the chance to practice in both community and hospital settings. They will be assisted in the development of clinical problemsolving skills and on the use of a nursing care plan in clinical settings. This will greatly support students in their transition to become Registered Nurses. Hence, a three-month continuous clinical practice period will be arranged within these clinical practice blocks. Furthermore, students are facilitated to be integrated into the health care team in clinical practice.
outcome: Students will be able to: 1. Identify the roles of different discipline in the care of clients and their family members with complex health problem. 2. Apply problem-solving approach in the identification and management of biopsychosocial health-related problems of clients. 3. Demonstrate a comprehensive and focused health assessment of individuals. Critically analyze health assessment data to identify, prioritize problems, and develop plans of care supported by research evidences. 4. Demonstrate competence in the safe and efficient performance of nursing skills in various clinical specialties, and in preparation and aftercare for investigative procedures. 5. Demonstrate effective communication with clients, their families, and multidisciplinary health care team members. 6. In partnership with client, facilitate the client’s psychosocial adaptation to experiencing moderate to severe health problems. 7. Establish ability to identify research topics from theoretical knowledge and practical experience.  8. Develop critical thinking skills and clinical judgment from theoretical knowledge and practical experience. 9. Demonstrate skills in self and peer appraisals of nursing techniques and care through reflections. 10. Evaluate and document assessment, care planning and implementation of care. 11. Demonstrate skills of coordinating the care for a group of clients.

title: Seminar
requirements: For students in PhD Nursing
description: The seminars, offered in each term of the programme, aim to help students gain skills in presenting and developing their ideas for their research study as well as allowing the exchange of ideas and methodological issues between students and academic staff contributing to the development of the student's thesis.

title: Applied Biological Science in Advanced Nursing Practice
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing and Master of Nursing
description: The course is deigned to integrate physiology, pathophysiology, genetics and clinical implications across the lifespan for advanced nursing practice. Recent scientific advances will be discussed with application to patient education and counselling, disease and symptom management, and to support clinical decision making for restoring and maintaining health.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. discuss the normal function of body systems and key structural and functional changes of major body systems across the lifespan.  2. identify and discuss pathophysiology of common disorders that affect main body systems and pathological process across the lifespan.  3. discuss genetic/genomic basis of health, illness, disease risk, and treatment response.  4. demonstrate the ability to apply knowledge in physiology, pathophysiology and genetics/genomics in health assessment, patient education and counselling, and therapeutic management of actual and potential health problems.

title: Advanced Health Assessment and Diagnostic Investigation
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing and Master of Nursing
description: This course is designed to equip students with advanced clinical assessment skills for advanced practice. The course covers comprehensive assessment of individuals, interpretation of clinical data and diagnostic investigation, consideration of differential diagnosis and evidence-based diagnostic reasoning, clinical decision making process for identifying health problems, and clinical judgment through analysis of clinical findings.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. perform and document comprehensive health history and physical assessments in a selected area of health care. 2. compare and contrast the principles and techniques in advanced health assessment including physical, psychological, socio-cultural, family and community assessments.  3. critically analyse the measures of diagnostic accuracy in evidence-based diagnostic reasoning. 4. demonstrate the ability to interpret and explain the clinical significance of abnormal clinical data and the underlying mechanisms of disease.  5.  demonstrate the ability to justify their clinical decisions by drawing upon theoretical principles, clinical findings and practical experience.

title: Therapeutic Design and Management
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: The course offers students with opportunities to apply their knowledge and skills related to clinical decision making in pharmacotherapeutic and clinical reasoning for developing a patient care plan to manage the identified health problems. The course covers advanced principles of clinical pharmacology and therapeutics of several common diseases or conditions, various disease management models, and how these guide students through the process of clinical reasoning and decision making, and the development of a client-centred care plan.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. advance knowledge of pharmaceutical, pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic properties of the medication. 2. critically analyse medication management in relation to individual’s characteristics and clinical conditions. 3. apply appropriate monitoring in assessing the impact and efficacy of the medication. 4. demonstrate ability to incorporate analysis of clinical and diagnostic data in the clinical decision making process. 5. critically appraise various disease management models in the care of clients with complex healthcare needs. 6. formulate a client-centred care plan to address complex healthcare needs according to various disease management models, taking into consideration the differential diagnosis and the interpretation of assessment and clinical data. 7. demonstrate the ability of providing education and counselling to the client/family regarding the medication regimens and care plan.

title: Health Information Systems and Patient Care Technology
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing and Master of Nursing
description: The course aims to provide students with an overview of fundamental concepts and issues regarding technology and information systems within the context of the healthcare system. The course covers theoretical models of health and nursing informatics, healthcare computing, information processing and management, data acquisition and representation, ethical and social issues in healthcare informatics.

title: Human Resource and Financial Management in Health Care
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: The aim of this course is to provide students with knowledge and skills in human resource and financial management in health care. Emphasis is placed on contemporary issues including nursing workforce planning, human resource management, innovative team development, financial management, resource allocation and budgeting.

title: Health Policy and Advocacy
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: The course aims to enable students to contribute towards the development of governance and its impact within their organisation. The course also offers analytical insights into understanding health policy making within the context of economic, legal, social justice and ethical issues. Discussions will be made regarding strategies that influence health policy outcomes.

title: Clinical and Translational Research in Nursing
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: This course is offered in Term 1 to pair up with NURS7114 as a year-long course. The course aims to equip students with knowledge on theoretical, methodological and statistical concepts for the development, implementation and evaluation of clinical and translational research in nursing. Emphasis is placed on the processes of critical appraisal, analysis and integration of research evidence, developing clinical questions for scientific inquiry, obtaining and appraising best evidence, and applying the evidence to inform professional development of clinical nursing.

title: Clinical and Translational Research in Nursing
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: This 4-unit course is offered in Term 2 to pair up with NURS7113 as a year-long course. The course aims to equip students with knowledge on theoretical, methodological and statistical concepts for the development, implementation and evaluation of clinical and translational research in nursing. Emphasis is placed on the processes of critical appraisal, analysis and integration of research evidence, developing clinical questions for scientific inquiry, obtaining and appraising best evidence, and applying the evidence to inform professional development of clinical nursing.

title: Research Seminar
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: This course is offered in Term 1 each study year to pair up with NURS7124 as a year-long course. The course aims at enabling students to develop skills in scholarly presentation and discussions and enhance their critical thinking abilities in planning, implementing, evaluating and applying evidence-based nursing innovations. The seminar also facilitates sharing of research ideas and methodological issues between doctoral students and academic staff, contributing to the development of the students’ evidence-based practice Research Projects.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. Critically discuss their own and others’ research problems and the significance of their research to the professional development in nursing. 2. Understand the applications of different research methodologies as scientific tools to address various clinical and professional issues in nursing.3. Critically discuss and evaluate the methodological issues arising from research presentations. 4. Disseminate their research proposals and findings effectively, and demonstrate the techniques to justify all the decisions involved in the study design, interpretation of results and discussions. 5. Engage constructively in the scholarly discussion of research presentations.

title: Research Seminar
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: This seminar with 2-unit weighting is offered in Term 2 each study year to pair up with NURS7123 as a year-long course. The seminar aims at enabling students to develop skills in scholarly presentation and discussions, and enhance their critical thinking abilities in planning, implementing, evaluating and applying evidence-based nursing innovations. The seminar also facilitates sharing of research ideas and methodological issues between doctoral students and academic staff, contributing to the development of the students’ evidence-based practice Research Projects.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. Critically discuss their own and others’ research problems and the significance of their research to the professional development in nursing.  2. Understand the applications of different research methodologies as scientific tools to address various clinical and professional issues in nursing. 3. Critically discuss and evaluate the methodological issues arising from research presentations.  4. Disseminate their research proposals and findings effectively, and demonstrate the techniques to justify all the decisions involved in the study design, interpretation of results and discussions.  5. Engage constructively in the scholarly discussion of research presentations.

title: Innovation in Advanced Nursing Practice: Theory, Application and Evaluation
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing or MPhil-PhD in Nursing
description: The aim of this course is to enable students to explore and critically analyse the process of developing, implementing and evaluating innovations in advanced nursing practice. The course consists of three major components: 1) providing students with opportunities to critically examine the epistemological debates about nursing science, and the influences of classical and contemporary nursing theories in shaping the innovative development of advanced nursing practice; 2) explore and critically discuss the innovative models of advanced nursing practice and the contemporary issues in the application of such models across the continuum of care; and 3) critically discuss the strategies and methods for identifying nurse sensitive outcomes in the evaluation of the effects and cost of advanced nursing practice.

title: Healthcare Management and Leadership
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing, Master of Nursing and MPhil-PhD in Nursing
description: This course aims to enable students to develop an advanced level of knowledge and skills in nursing leadership and healthcare management. The course covers examination of healthcare organisations, theories and methods for improving the quality, safety and outcomes of healthcare services, service planning, mentorship, transformational leadership and future nursing development in the local and global contexts.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. develop personal vision, mission and values. 2. critically explore the concepts, theories, and innovative models in advanced clinical leadership and healthcare management. 3. critically discuss the core concepts, processes and strategies for developing an organisational culture. 4. demonstrate the ability to systematically and comprehensively analyse the complexities of service development, improvement and innovation. 5. demonstrate a detailed understanding of the approaches or techniques used to plan/ lead the development, implementation and evaluation of services. 6. demonstrate an appreciation of the dynamic changes and the need for transformational leadership and mentorship in nursing. 7. conceptualise the future of nursing from the local and global perspectives.

title: Transforming Health Care through Professional Collaborations and Client-professional Partnership
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing and Master of Nursing
description: The course aims to help students develop expertise needed for taking a leadership role in working with others within a team and collaborating with other teams. The course covers contemporary issues in healthcare professions, concepts and competencies for inter-professional collaboration, barriers and facilitators to achieving a model of collaborative practice. The course also enables students to discuss innovative opportunities to change current practice, and client-professional partnership models for transforming care.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. employ effective communication and collaborative skills in the development and implementation of practice models and guidelines, standard of care and health policy. 2. demonstrate the ability to lead interprofessional teams in the analysis of complex practice and organisational issues. 3. demonstrate the ability to collaborate with members of the healthcare team to provide and promote interprofessional client-centred care at individual, organisational and system levels.  4. demonstrate the ability to develop and maintain client’s control over decision making, assess the client’s commitment to the jointly determined plan of care, and foster personal responsibility for health.  5. critically appraise the implications of clinical partnership and collaboration in healthcare transformation.

instructors:
Dr. NG Shek Nam, 
Professor CHENG Ho Yu

title: Clinical Reasoning and Decision Making in Advanced Nursing Practice
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing, MPhil-PhD in Nursing and Master of Nursing
description: This course aims to enable students to utilise their acquired knowledge and skills to make accurate clinical judgments and decisions in the delivery of safe and effective care in a variety of healthcare settings. The course covers the impact of clinical reasoning and clinical decision making on patient outcomes and safety, decision making frameworks and tools, and steps in the process of clinical decision making. Students are provided with opportunities of using skills learned in this course to address the identified clinical situation to ensure safe and effective care implementation.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. critically discuss the concepts of clinical reasoning and clinical decision making.  2. critically discuss the impact of nurses’ clinical reasoning and decision making on patient outcomes and safety.  3. critically examine decision making frameworks and tools for providing effective and efficient care.  4. demonstrate the ability to go through the clinical decision making process and justify their clinical decisions based on theoretical principles, practical experiences and ethical stance.  5. evaluate decisions in terms of health outcomes of the patient and efficacy of healthcare services, with consideration from patient’s and family’s perspectives.

title: Advanced Nursing Practice in a Global Context
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: The aim of this course is to prepare students for active roles and develop their competencies in nursing leadership, advanced clinical decision making and evidence-based nursing innovations for managing the complex healthcare environment in a global context. Students will be provided with an intensive overseas clinical shadowing experience in high-quality healthcare organisations. They will also be provided with opportunities and guidance in using reflective approach to optimise their learning outcomes through clinical exposure. By the end of this course, they will be able to conduct a critical discussion on how the advanced model in nursing service provision can be applied to the healthcare systems in their own countries.

title: Clinical Practicum
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: The aim of this clinical practicum is to prepare students for active roles and develop their competences in nursing leadership, advanced clinical decision making and evidence-based nursing innovations for managing the complex health care environment. Students will be provided with an intensive overseas clinical shadowing experience in high quality health care organizations. They will also be provided with opportunities and guidance in using reflective approach to optimize their learning outcomes through clinical exposure. By the end of this course, they will be able to conduct a critical discussion on how the advanced model in nursing service provision can be applied to the health care systems in their own countries.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. Critically evaluate the integration of theory and practice in clinical setting.  2. Analyse and evaluate different approaches and models of nursing leadership, clinical decision making and advanced nursing practice in clinical setting.  3. Critically reflect, analyse, reconsider and examine their own clinical experiences relating to nursing leadership, clinical decision making and advance nursing practice.  4. Critically evaluate the health care outcomes in relation to different approaches in nursing leadership, clinical decision making and advanced nursing practice.

title: Thesis Research
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD in Nursing
description: This research unit provides students with continuing supervision and monitoring of their progress in developing and writing up their theses.
outcome: The course will enable students to: 1. Initiate an empirical study in a selected area 2. Apply appropriate research methodology to address the empirical inquiry and theory to underpin the study 3. Examine critical problem solving strategies in conducting the research study 4. Demonstrate the knowledge in data management including data collection, data analysis and data interpretation 5. Discuss the implications of the research for nursing practice  6. Formulate nursing knowledge/theory from the study results 7. Demonstrate the academic ability in writing up a dissertation which entails sufficient amount of the details to permit a thorough critique of the overall research study

title: Research Project Supervision
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: This course is offered in Term 2 of Year 2 to provide students with individual evidence-based practice research supervision. The students are coached to critically apply the knowledge generated from their clinical and translational research to develop an evaluation protocol. This protocol will be used to evaluate the effectiveness of the nursing innovation developed in NURS 8112 at individual, organizational and/ or community levels. The students are required to obtain ethical approval for conducting scientific evaluation of the nursing innovation.

title: Research Project Supervision
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: This course is offered in Term 2 of Year 3 to provide students with individual evidence-based practice research supervision in client sampling, implementation of nursing innovation, process monitoring, and data collection. The students are provided with opportunities to critically integrate their knowledge into clinical and translational research, clinical leadership and decision making, as well as advanced nursing practice to facilitate successful implementation of the nursing innovation. This course enables students to consolidate the knowledge that they have learnt in the previous study years and translate such knowledge to real practice.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. Demonstrate appropriate techniques to accurately implement the innovative nursing protocol. 2. Demonstrate appropriate techniques to monitor the integrity of the innovative nursing protocol and response promptly and appropriately to undesirable adverse events.  3. Demonstrate appropriate techniques to collect research data and to maximize data validity and reliability. 4. Demonstrate appropriate techniques to monitor and record any factors which may influence the evaluative outcomes of the innovative nursing protocol. 5. Demonstrate appropriate techniques to manage research data.  6. Demonstrate appropriate techniques to respond appropriately to barriers which hinder evaluative data collection.  7. Demonstrate appropriate techniques to ensure that ethical principles and guidelines are strictly followed in the implementation of nursing innovation.

title: Research Project Supervision
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: This course is offered in Term 1 of Year 4 to pair up with NURS8104 as a year-long course. The course provides students with individual evidence-based practice research supervision in the process of analysing the data collected for evaluating the nursing innovation and reviewing the process of its implementation. The students are provided with opportunities to interpret the study findings, critically discuss the implications of the findings on advanced nursing practice, nursing professional development and nursing science advancement. The course also enables students to discuss a systematic plan on how to translate the developed evidence to immediate nursing practice.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. Apply appropriate methods to conduct qualitative and quantitative data analysis for evaluating the evidence-based innovative nursing protocol.2. Present evaluative data in an orderly, logical, systematic, and accurate manner.3. Accurately interpret research data and make relevant and appropriate conclusions on clinical effectiveness and applicability of the evidence-based innovative nursing protocol. 4. Critically discuss and integrate research findings in the context of existing nursing knowledge and explain similarities and differences.5. Critically consider the limitations of the study and their associated impacts on research findings. 6. Critically discuss the clinical implications of the research findings for nursing practice, nursing theory and/ or nursing research.7. Demonstrate the academic skills in writing up a thesis which entails sufficient amount of details to permit a thorough critique of the overall research study.

title: Research Project Supervision
requirements: For students in Doctor of Nursing
description: This 5-unit course is offered in Term 2 of Year 4 to pair up with NURS8103 as a year-long course. The course provides students with individual evidence-based practice research supervision in the process of analysing the data collected for evaluating the nursing innovation and reviewing the process of its implementation. The students are provided with opportunities to critically discuss the implications of the evaluative findings on advanced nursing practice, nursing professional development and nursing science advancement. The course also enables the students to discuss a systematic plan on how to translate the developed evidence to immediate nursing practice. By the end of this course, the students are required to integrate theoretical and clinical knowledge in their empirical research study and submitting a thesis for assessment prior to graduation.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  1. Apply appropriate qualitative or quantitative methods to conduct data analysis for evaluating the evidence based innovative nursing protocol. 2. Present the evaluative data in an orderly, logical, systematic, and accurate manner. 3. Critically interpret evaluative data to examine clinical effectiveness of the evidence-based innovative nursing protocol. 4. Critically consider the alternative explanations of the findings and present scientific rationale for their rejection. 5. Critically consider the limitations of the study and their associated impacts on research findings.  6. Critically discuss the clinical implications of the research findings for nursing practice, nursing theory and/ or nursing research. 7. Demonstrate the academic skills in writing up a thesis which entails sufficient amount of details to permit a thorough critique of the overall research study.
